Key Works: Fitzsimmons (1983, diss.); Tananbaum (1986, diss.); Hosgood (1989, article)
Core Findings & Emphases: Shopkeeping structured around family enterprise; women and children’s labor indispensable; continuity across upheavals (Fitzsimmons). Shopkeepers projected respectability while facing precarity (Tananbaum). Hosgood highlights household survival strategies among marginal petty traders.

Key Works: LeYaouanq (1979, article); Fitzsimmons (1983, diss.); Rogers (1995, diss.); Jones (1991, diss.); Morris (1989, diss.); Hosgood (1989, article)
Core Findings & Emphases: Shopkeepers often first-generation urbanites with limited intergenerational continuity (LeYaouanq). Marriage alliances, neighborhood ties, and dowries crucial (Fitzsimmons). English and Italian studies confirm shopkeepers as transitional class fractions, subject to bankruptcy, precarity, and fragile reproduction.

Key Works: Nord (1981, article); Coombs (1996, diss.); Cairns (1974, article); Chatelain (1971, article); Hosgood (1989, article)
Core Findings & Emphases: French shopkeepers mobilized in anti-statist, corporatist, right-wing populist movements (Nord). Coombs: cyclical surges toward the far right, but recurrent demobilization. Cairns: stereotype of “nation of shopkeepers” as national identity trope. Chatelain: 19th-c. peddler/shopkeeper conflicts politicized. Hosgood: petty traders perceived as problematic “pigmies,” yet resilient.

Research Question / Theme: 4. Corporatism, the State, and Institutional Embedding
Key Works: Jones (1982, article); Shorb (2005, diss.); Coombs (1996, diss.)
Core Findings & Emphases: Vichy corporatism institutionalized merchant elite, reforms persisted postwar (Jones). Shorb: Japan’s corporatist bargain between shopkeepers and state (guilds, neighborhood associations). Coombs: French shopkeepers integrated into commercial interest-group systems that moderated radicalization.

Key Works: Loberg (2006, diss.); Chatelain (1971, article); Hosgood (1989, article)
Core Findings & Emphases: Shopkeepers central in contested urban spaces. Loberg: Berlin streets as arenas of commerce/politics, antisemitism culminating in Kristallnacht. Chatelain: urban shopkeepers vs. itinerant peddlers. Hosgood: petty traders as essential to working-class provisioning in Manchester markets.

Key Works: Zalc (2010, book; Coquery 2012 review); Coquery (2012, review)
Core Findings & Emphases: Rejects essentialist notions of “ethnic entrepreneur.” Immigrant shopkeepers’ trajectories shaped by legal surveillance (1919 Trade Register), xenophobia, crises, not nationality per se. Highlights the erosion of liberty of trade and the importance of local context in immigrant integration.
